skill.name: no-hardcoding
skill.description: Forbid hardcoded values in code. Use this when reviewing code, writing new features, or when magic numbers/strings are detected. Enforces constants, env variables, and config files.
skill.summary: Enforce code quality by eliminating hardcoded values and magic numbers
skill.author: Doyajin174

security_audit.summary: This skill is safe to publish. All static findings are false positives from documentation examples showing what NOT to do. The skill contains code examples demonstrating bad practices with hardcoded credentials and URLs, but these are purely educational examples in markdown documentation to teach developers what to avoid. No actual executable code with security risks exists.

content.user_title: Eliminate Hardcoded Values from Your Codebase
content.value_statement: Hardcoded values create maintenance nightmares and security risks. This skill helps Claude Code detect and refactor magic numbers, hardcoded strings, URLs, and credentials into properly organized constants and environment variables.
actual_capabilities: Detect magic numbers and strings in code during reviews
Identify hardcoded URLs, API endpoints, and configuration values
Suggest proper constant extraction and naming conventions
Guide environment variable setup and validation patterns
Provide file organization structure for constants and config
Enforce best practices for credential management
limitations: Cannot automatically detect all context-specific magic values
Requires user judgment for exceptions like 0, 1, -1 in obvious contexts
Does not execute or validate actual environment variable values
Limited to pattern-based detection in visible code files

use_cases.title: Code Review for Production Readiness
use_cases.description: Review pull requests to ensure no hardcoded credentials, API keys, or configuration values make it to production. Automatically suggest proper environment variable usage.
use_cases.target_user: Engineering teams preparing code for deployment

use_cases.title: Legacy Code Refactoring
use_cases.description: Scan legacy codebases to identify and extract magic numbers and strings into well-organized constant files. Improve code maintainability and reduce technical debt.

use_cases.title: New Feature Development
use_cases.description: Enforce best practices from the start by guiding developers to use constants and environment variables. Create proper configuration structure for new modules.
use_cases.target_user: Developers building new features or microservices

best_practices: Extract any numeric or string literal used more than once into a named constant
Store all environment-specific values like URLs and API keys in environment variables with validation
Organize constants by domain in separate files under a constants directory for better maintainability
anti_patterns: Leaving magic numbers without comments or context, making code meaning unclear to future developers
Storing sensitive credentials in code files or committing them to version control systems
Creating constants for obvious values like 0, 1, -1 in simple array operations where meaning is clear

faq.question: What exactly is a magic number or magic string?
faq.answer: A magic number or string is a literal value in code without clear meaning or context. For example, if (users.length > 100) uses a magic number. Better would be const MAX_USERS = 100; if (users.length > MAX_USERS) which makes the intent clear.

faq.question: When should I use constants versus environment variables?
faq.answer: Use constants for values that are the same across all environments like business rules or UI limits. Use environment variables for values that change between development, staging, and production like API URLs, database connections, or API keys.

faq.question: Are there any numbers that do not need to be extracted as constants?
faq.answer: Yes, common values like 0, 1, -1 in obvious contexts like array indexing or simple math operations are acceptable. For example, array[0] or total / 2 are clear enough without constants.

faq.question: How does this skill help with security?
faq.answer: This skill helps prevent accidentally committing sensitive credentials, API keys, or database passwords to version control by enforcing the use of environment variables for all sensitive values.

faq.question: Can this skill automatically refactor my code?
faq.answer: Yes, when used with Claude Code, it can suggest specific refactorings and even apply them with your approval. It will extract constants, create proper file structures, and update environment variable configurations.

faq.question: What file structure does this skill recommend for constants?
faq.answer: It recommends a constants directory with domain-specific files like constants/api.ts, constants/ui.ts, and constants/business.ts. Each exports const objects with meaningful names. A config/env.ts file handles environment variable validation and typing.
